item.description:
Suburban touring at its best!

Chestnut Hill is a classic streetcar suburb which developed as the railroad and streetcar network expanded around Boston. By the early twentieth century, Chestnut Hill was considered to be suburban living at its best.

This walking tour explores the Newton portion of the Chestnut Hill neighborhood where you will walk among large Victorian mansions while learning its evolution from rural farmland once owned by the Hammonds, Lees, and Lawrences to a modern suburb.

Chestnut Hill also features the home of the Eagles and the historic Chestnut Hill Reservoir with a finish at the new Metropolitan WaterWorks Museum where you can see the 1894 550 HP Leavitt Engine (No. 3) in the High Service Pumping Station.

Come along and discover this hidden enclave of Victorian estates on this walk up and down Chestnut Hill. Be forewarned, it's a fairly long route and there is a hill (hence the name) so dress for some walking. Also this tour has a non-circular route. So if you park at the starting location you'll have about a 10 minute walk back to your car. For those taking the T, we'll end just by the next stop along the green line.

Tour costs $15 for the general public (it is $5 for card-carrying Boston By Foot members. Tour will proceed regardless of the weather and reservations are not required.
item.how_to_find_us: Look for folks with Boston By Foot stuff in the parking lot of the Chestnut Hill T Station.
item.name: Chestnut Hill Walking Tour
